div.head: Regarding the text
div.p:
Nunc ad distinctionem personarum
Lombardus, Sent. I, d. 9, c. 1 (I, 103, ll. 6).
. This is the ninth distinction of this first book in which after the Master determined about divine generation, now he determines about the coeternal generation of the Father and the Son. And he divides this into two parts because he first shows their coeternity wither respect to the intrinsic mode of being, in the second place with respect to the mode of speaking or signifying. The second begins at
hic quaeri potest Lombardus, Sent. I, d. 9, c. 4 (I, 106, ll. 3). .

The first is divided into four because in the first place puts forward the distinction of the divine persons, second he considers their equal duration, third he introduces against this the objection of the heretics, fourth he defeats the presumption of the opposition. The second begins at
genitus est enim
Lombardus, Sent. I, d. 9, c. 2 (I, 103, ll. 15).
. The third at
sed contra hoc
Lombardus, Sent. I, d. 9, c. 2 (I, 103, ll. 18).
. The fourth at
sed quaeris
Lombardus, Sent. I, d. 9, c. 3 (I, 105, ll. 3).

The second principal part is divided into three because first he introduces a disputable opinion, second harmonized the apparent disagreement of the doctors, third he introduces the conclusion that should be held about this matter. The second begins at
dicamus ergo Filium Lombardus, Sent. I, d. 9, c. 4 [n.8/13], (I, 109, ll. 6). . The third at
Sed inquiet haeretics
L leaves a blank here, and the supplied incipit "sed inquiet haereticis" is a likely suggestion of the likely referenced intended by Gracilis.
Lombardus, Sent. I, d. 9, c. 5 [n.1], (I, 109, ll. 29). . This is the division of this lecture.

div.head: Question
div.p: Whether priority of any durative measure is repugnant to a supposite or person of a divine nature?

div.head: Principal arguments
div.p: That not because the Word is the measure of a creature, therefore the Word is not coeternal with the Father. The antecedent is clear and the consequence is proved because equal and proportionate in a measured way to what it measures.

In the second place the divine Word is immense, therefore it is not measured by eternity because it seems to be a contradiction for the immense to be measured. The antecedent is a catholic truth. This is confirmed because the Word is above and beyond eternity, therefore it is not measured by eternity. Elsewhere it is proved in Exodus chapter 3:
The Lord will reign for ever and ever Exodus 15:18 .

In the third place, eternity is made, therefore the Word is not eternity, nor is it measured by it. The antecedent is clear through Augustine in 83 questions
where he says:
God is the author of eternity Augustinus, De diversis quaestionibus octoginta tribus q.23 (CCSL 44A, 27, ll. 11-12) . Again Boethius says that
sicut nunc fluens facit temporis sic nunc stans et permanens facit aeternitatem Boetius, XXX .
In opposition is the claim of the Master of the Sentences in this distinction. Again, in a similar way, in this Trinity there is not prior or posterior, etc.

div.head: First conclusion
div.p:
The first conclusion: though eternally or the duration of eternity in abstract to world outside itself is not a communicable perfection, nevertheless this is an eternal and formal measure of whatever is produced. The first part is because it would follow that a creature would be able to be coeternal with God or that any creature would be produced before some time, but each of these options is false or impossible, therefore. The second part is proved because the properties of measure do not properly suit God with respect to a creature and not only transumptively, therefore. The antecedent is show by Giles, in book two, distinction eight, question three, in part two since the ratio of number fits himself temporally, uniformally, absolutely, and indivisibly. Secondly, because ratio of adequation suits the the creature in two ways, namely through conformity and imitation, therefore it follows that God is causally, formally the measure of any produced being. The first part of the conclusion is confirmed because invariability, immutability, and simultaneity, therefore not eternity. The consequence is clear because these are properties of eternity as will be clear later. And the antecedent is clear because according to Gregory
in that in which a creature is, it has the vicissitude of changeability Gregorius Magnus, Moralia, V, c. 37, 4 .

The first corollary: immensity and eternity of measure do not infer the immensity of the measured nature, against
John of Marchia, in the first question of his Sentences, in his determination in the response of the first argument against the second conclusion . This is clear because the immense God is the formal measure of the creature, and nevertheless the creature is not immense, and as a consequence is not proportionally adequate to him, as he says there.

The second corollary: the ratio of formal eternity is not a denomination of perfection absolutely. This is clear because any such perfection is communicable outside itself to a creature concretely, but eternity is not communicable to a creature, therefore.
From the first corollary and conclusion it follows that any material and divisible nature is measured by an immaterial and indivisible measure in some mode and not adequately.

The third corollary: though eternity as such is not a perfection as if absolutely denotively, nevertheless it is a mode of perfection in identity, really, and entitatively. The first part is clear through the
second corollary Vide supra . The second is proved because eternity is essentially the eternal God.

div.head: Second conclusion
div.p:
The second conclusion: just as the highest goodness is its own supersimple nature, so it is its own eternity and every measure of it. This is proved through Anselm Monologion 24 where he says
it stands that the highest substance exists without a beginning and an end, nor does it have a present, past, or future Anselmus, Monologion 24,(I, 42, ll. 11-12). . Item
Alexander in the book On the memory of difficult things, proposition 52 says
tempus rem a suo principio distare facit aeternitas vero rem suae causae continuat[?] et coniungit in aeternitate non est pars neque prius aut posterius Alexander, XXX . Again proposition 44 says that
nullum immutabile mensuratur
mensura successiva aut succedente sed aeterna Alexander de Alexandria, De memoria rerum difficilium, prop. 44
.

The first corollary: the measure of any divine operation or causality is an every present and indivisible instant of eternity. This is clear because God is his own operation taken nominally and actively, therefore. This is confirmed because both God and creature are measured by eternity, and as a consequence by this instant because they are precisely the same thing.

The second corollary: a plurality of gods is as repugnant to divinity as multiplicity of signs is repugnant to eternity. therefore any measure of it is totally adequate to it. But any sign or instant of eternity is a proper measure of it, therefore any such thing is simple and not multiple. And I understand through equal measure with God lasting supersimple permanence and being independent and without a beginning.

Third corollary: just as eternity is a measure intrinsecly exlcuding a plurality of signs, so an instant of eternity is including contentively every durative succession. The first part is opposed to Scotum in many places which is proved thus because otherwise the entire Trinity will be more multiple than its signification, which is false and against the
second corollary Vide supra . Again the sign would be simpler than its eternity, which is false. The second part is against Hugolino which is proved because the instant of eternity is adequately this instant of eternity, therefore any instant of eternity is a precontentive instant of eternity contentively including this and inclusively containing this. But eternity precontains and includes every successive durative pause both real and imaginative, therefore.

div.head: Tertia conclusio
div.p:
Third conclusion: the generation of the eternal word or to generate eternally in an instant of eternity is considered to be measured. This is clear through Damescenus, in book one, chapter 8
divine generation is without beginning and eternal, existing as a work of nature Ioannes Damascenus, De fide orthodoxa, I, 8, (PG 94, 813: Buytaert 32, 77-80) . Again this is proved by reason because this generation is invariable, incorruptible, simultaneous without succession, but these are properties of eternity, therefore. The first part of the antecedent is clear, and the second is through Augustine III De Trinitate, chapter three who says that
God is true eternity Augustinus, De Trinitate, III . Again in IV De Trinitate, chapter 19
his true eternity is unchangeable Augustinus, De Trinitate, IV, 18, 24
To the same speaks Giles, in distinction 8 of book 1, the second part, question two where he posits these properties inforam

The first corollary: it is not the case that the Word is able to be called for any sign and in that instant this is not produced through generation, which is contrary to
Scotus, in distinction 22 of book 1, in the second question Scotus, Ordinatio, I, d. 22, q. 2 . This is proved because if in some sign the Father were able to generate the Son and for that instant he would not generate him, it follows that generation would not be measured by an instant lacking a beginning. The consequent is false through what has been said. The consequence is clear because the first sign in which a first person is habitually fecund would precede the generation of the Son, and as a consequence for that instant there will be a preceding negation of the word, which is false.

The second corollary: for any sign the Father generates an only begotten, while the Son spirates the Holy Spirit with the same sign, contra Scotus, where it is proved above, and in the sign the first sign of the origin in which the Father is fecund and the Son not according to him. And let this sign be a and the second sign in which the Son is fecund be b, then in this case a has a separate negation of fecundity of the Son, therefore in a the Son is not fecund, and a is before b, therefore the Son is not fecund prior to the point when he is fecund. The consequence is clear because a is prior, b is posterior, otherwise a would not be first and b second as he says. But this consequent is false because then the Son would begin to be fecund and he would not be fecund without beginning against what has been said, therefore the corollary is true.

The third corollary is the affirmative title of the question which is proved by
Lord Alphonsus, in distinction one Alphonsus Vargas, I, d. 1, xxx , see there. This is confirmed because in the divine there is not some priority besides some origin not in any place. I do not intend to deny through what has been said in this question because I speak only about the measurative priority against Scotus's way of speaking who thinks that in
an instant of eternity there are three signs of the origin. In the first are all the essentials, namely knowledge, wisdom, goodness, etc. In the second the Father generates the Son. In the third he spirates the Holy Spirit and he says consequently that the Father spirates the Holy Spirit from an origin prior to that of the Son, see
Alphonsus, in distinction 9 of the first book Alphonsus Vargas, I, d. 9, ?? . The responsive corollary Alphonsus proves thus, virtually in the Son and to any divine person for any sign of the origin or nature it is repugnatn not to be, therefore also to be posterior, therefore no person is prior to the other. The antecedent is clear because it is necessary in the highest degree. And the consequence is clear because, for if for some some sign one person is prior, then another is posterior. But therefore in that sign the Son has being or not. If yes, then in that instant the Father is not prior to him. If not, then the Son has being after non being and thus is produced from non being to being. The consequence is clear because in the second he has being, indeed it follows that no being is not repugnant to the Son which in opposition to the antecedent.

div.head: Objections
div.p:
Against the first conclusion: God is not of the same genus as created things, therefore he is not the measure of created things. This consequence is clear through the
Philosopher X Metaphysicae
who says
the measure out to be one Augustine, Metaphysicae, X , that is, of one genus when measured.
Secondly, God is not proportional to a creature. Again, he is not replicable. Again, quantity applies neither to God or eternity, but these are the properties of measure, therefore.

Against the second conclusion and its corollaries: if eternal measure were proper intrinsically to any divine operation, it follows that divine doing would be eternal. The consequent does not seem true, but the consequence appears because then when the divine willing is eternal and the divine willing is doing, it follows that the divine doing is eternal, and thus all things would be made from this eternality.

In the second place, it follows that two contradictories in an instant of eternity are true at the same time. The consequent is false. The consequence is proved because in one mode God does not wish that Christ suffers, and this not wishing is eternal. And he wishes that Christ suffers, therefore this wishing was eternal. And thus in the same instant he wishes and does not wish or is unwilling, which are contradictories.

In the third place, if he wishes equally in the present that being would be and the past being would be, it follows that it would be equally necessary that one is just as much as the other. The consequent is false.

In the fourth place, against the corollaries: everything that one says is indivisible indivisibly is simpler than what one says is indivisible and not indivisibly. But one says that the sign or instant of eternity is truly indivisible, but not indivisibly, therefore etc.

In the fifth place, against the second and third corollary, there is the position of John 16, where it is said about the spirit that
it speaks whatever it hears Ioannes 16:13 . But it is certain that the future is not able to be carried back unless to the some eternal sign, and thus there will be many signs in eternity. Again John 12
glorify me father with glory which I had with you before the word began John 17:5 . Again against the conclusion it is the position of
Boethius
augustini boetii
alleged earlier because if eternity is made, it follows that it is not God. Again, there is the authority of Augustine.
Against the third conclusion is argument made in the opposition because the the divine word, etc.

In the second place, through
Exodus 3
The Lord will reign for ever and ever Exodus 15:18

In the third place, passive generation and the Son have a beginning, therefore its duration has a beginning. The consequence is clear because they are the same. The antecedent is clear through Augustine V De Trinitate 14 who says
the Father is the beginning of the Son Augustine, De Trinitate, V .
In the fourth place, in the divine is number. The antecedent is clear because of the Trinity. And the consequence is clear because in any number duality follows unity and unity precedes it.

In the fifth place, whatever is near to the first thing seems to be prior. But the Son is nearer to the first thing because it is more immediate to the Father, therefore the Son is prior to the Holy Spirit and similarly the Father to the Son. The major is known and the minor is proved because the Holy Spirit proceeds from the Father mediated by the Son.

For a solition of the arguments aginst the first conclusion, it should be known that measure is said in many ways. In one way through the replication of measure, and thus it is taken in the
X Metaphysics Aristoteles, Metaphysicae, X, xxx
about heavy things.
In the second mode through the likeness and approximation and imitation of other things to it.

In the third place it is taken according to the causality, priority, and determination, and thus the art is called the measure of the artificer, thus it is said in
V Metaphysics Aristoteles, Metaphysicase, V, xxx
about the intelligibile.
In the fourth mode according to the formal reformation or reception, and thus knowledge is said to be the measure of what is known.
In the fifth mode through the interposition of position and the hight of this position is the measure of this or that distance.
In the first and last modes, God is not said to be the measure, though he is correctly said to be the measure of things in the second, third, and fourth modes.

div.head: Responses
div.p: To the first, I say that by taking genus loosely for anything common verifying about many things either univocally or equivocally, it is thus able to be conceded that it is of the same genus with creatures because being is said about creatures and God in this mode.. But if genus is taken strictly and properly for something that is said about many things univocally, then only the antecedent is conceded and the consequence is denied, in the first place for that sense, but not in another.

To the second, it is said that though between God and creatures there is not proportion of adequation quantitatively, nevertheless there is between them a proportion of order or exemplar or imitating, and this is sufficient for him to be the measure of things.
To the third, the consequence is denied and to the proof it is said that replication is not about the ratio of measure absolutely, but only about the ratio of measure quantitatively.

To the fourth, the consequence is denied because, though the name of quantity was in potency to the things of quantity primarily and properly, nevertheless with this it stands that what is signified is suitable to God.

To the first against the second conclusion, the consequent is conceded, but nevertheless it is not eternal activity when about speaking about the activity of God outside himself. Further it would be able to be said that not every willing of God is an activity, though not the converse.

To the second, the consequence is denied. To the proof, I say that Christ suffers is able to be taken in two ways. In the first mode for the utterance or for this proposition, Christ suffers. In the second mode for the reality behind the utterance, namely for the moment in which Christ was suffering and for the passion of Christ. If it is taken in the first mode, the consequence is not proved because these propositions were not eternally existing. If in the second mode, then it is said that God wishes whatever he has ever wished and ever wish is present in his present instant of eternity where there is no change of the past or future. And through this solution many similar arguments in this matter are able to be solved.

To the third, the consequence is denied because this kind of necessity of past time does come from something intrinsic to divine knowledge, but rather from something extrinsic. Think for example because the thing posited is in actual existence.
To the fourth, the minor is denied because eternity is as simple and indivisible as an instant or sign of eternity is simple or indivisible and conversely.

To the fight about the Holy Spirit, here responds Augustine in homily 45 on John showing that we speak truly about God when we say he was and will be because he never will cease from being nor every did cease, not indeed because there is some plurality of signs in his very self.

In another way it is able to be ssaid that God, though he is not properly in time and the persons because they do not vary according to time through accident, nevertheless he is in time because when time, then the words of past and future of time are able to be said about God. This response is drawn from the words of
Giles, book 1, in this distinction part three, question four Aegidius Romanos, I, d. 9, p. 3, q. 4 .
In the third place, it is able to be said that the phrase before the world began to able be habitually, that is, if there were a time before the world began, he would have glory in that time.

In the fourth place, it would be able to be said that, if time were received for any imaginary possible positive or privative succession, then there was infinite time before the world because such things are to be taken as signs of what is imagined to succeed.
To Boethius who says that the now stands etc., it is conceded with respect to the apprehension of our mind or with respect to the cognition of our intellect.
To Augustine it is said that he speaks about a participated eternity and secundum quid, but not about eternity absolutely or he speaks about eternity a parte post..

To the first against the third
conclusion, it is said that, though the divine Word is unmeasure by any measure distinct from it, nevertheless it is said that it is measured by a measure which is its own eternity, as is shown by
Giles, in distinction 8 of the first book, part three, question three Aegidius Romanos, I, d. 8, p. 3, q. 3 .

To that argument from
Exodus 3 Exodus 15:18
it is said that eternity is taken in two ways, in one mode first for that period of any one natural life, in the second mode for the uniform and immmobile simutaneous existence. In the first mode it is conceded absolutely, but in the second it is denied.

In the second place, it would be able to be said according to Anselm in the Prosologion, chapter 3 that God is
beyond that ultra illa quae etiam finem non habebunt tum quia illa nullatenus sine eo esse possunt ipse autem non minus esse si omnia in nihilum irent tum secundo quia illa possunt cogitari habere finem Deus vero nequaquam Further because the eternity of God and them is in God completely, but not in them Anselmus, Prosologion c. 20. .

To the third, in the first place the consequence is denied because it would be possible to argue similarly that the essence would have a beginning because this is the same in the Son. Again it would be possible to be said that if beginning is taken for duration, then the Son and Holy Spirit have a beginning because just as the Father communicates deity to the Son, so also eternity. But if it is taken for a limitation of duration, then no divine person has a beginning.

To fourth concerning number, it is said that just as in the divine there is wisdom, magnitude, though nevertheless this is not a quality or quality, so there is a threeness, nevertheless it is not properly said in number, and about this it will be seen below.

To the fifth, the minor is denied because it is not therefore said that the Father produces the Holy Spirit through the mediation of the Son because the Father does not immediately produce it, but because the Father has from the Father the spirative power. But against this it is objected through Augustine, in book de triplici habitaculo where he says
the just in heaven will see what is between generation and spiration and they will see that the Father precedes the Son, not in nature, but in origin

Nevertheless to this Alphonsus says that Augustine wishes to say that among the Father and Son there is a priority of origin, not in which, but from which, that is, because the Son is from the Father by order of nature, nevertheless there is not there a real, durative, and measurative priority of signs, as Scotus and his followers try to prove, the arguments for which
Alphonsus solves in this ninth distinction Alphonsus, In Sent, I, d. 9 (XXX) . See there.

div.head: Conclusions for the ninth distinction
div.p: Now to the distinction of persons Lombardus, Sent. I, d. 9, c. 1 [n.1], (I, 103, ll. 6). . This distinction contains nine conclusions. First that the Father, and the Son, and the Holy Spirit are one God, nevertheless in nature the Father is not the Son, nor is the Son the Father, nor is the Holy Spirit the Father or the Son.

Second conclusion: there is one essence of the Father and the Son and the Holy Spirit in which there is not another Father, another Son, and another Holy Spirit, though personally there a Father which is other than the Son which is other than the Holy Spirit.
Third conclusion: though the Son is born from the Father, nevertheless the Father was not before the Son, but rather all three personas are coeternal and coequal with one another.
Fourth conclusion: just as splendor which is born from fire is coeternal with the fire or would be, so is the Son with the fire.

Fifth conclusion: when we say or name the father, we designate the son because no one is a father to himself. But when we name the son, we also acknowledge the son because non one is a son to himself, from which it follows that there is not able to be son without the father nor a father without the son, therefore there is always a father and a son.

Sixth conclusion: that the generation of the Son of God is ineffable because it is not able to be fully exemplified or understood by any mortals, though something about it is able to be understood and expressed.
The seventh conclusion: though it is able to be conceded that the Son is always born from the Father, it is more congruent to say that he always has been born.
Eight conclusion: that we admit that the only begotten God was born before time and was not born before being nor was in being before it was born. And thus concerning this distinction.
